Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Non-Toxic Electrodeposition Process for Structural Color
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be the development of a novel process to generate environmentally friendly, low-cost and robust structural color paints to address the increasing concerns over emission of toxic elements into the environment by the spray-painting of pigment-based paints, e.g. those used in automobile industry. It also provides a cost-effective solution for making structural colors without using expensive vacuum equipment. We propose a new process to immerse 3D shaped parts directly into specially prepared non-toxic chemical solutions to electrochemically deposit multilayered structural colors. The advantage of this proposed process is twofold: (1) it can potentially reduce the overall coating time by 20-30% (2) it can reduce carbon emissions and waste generation from the spray-painting process by 50%. In addition, structural colors can be designed to produce optical resonances in any wavelength, a property that makes it highly compatible with LiDAR systems. The coming mobility and autonomous driving era have opened a vast market for specially prepared reflective coatings that are specifically compatible with LiDAR systems, which presents an exciting opportunity for the optically designed structural colors. Lastly, because the design is flexible with the type of materials used to generate bright and vibrant colors, one can select materials that are bio-compatible and safe to wear on skin, which can open future applications for our technology in the cosmetics industry.

This I-Corps project involves the use of electrodeposition to generate metal-dielectric-metal multilayered structural color paints and has several clear advantages over traditional deposition or assembly methods for preparing colored films. Unlike pigment-based colors, structural colors generate color using the interference effect of light. Different colors of high brightness are achieved by simply tuning the thickness of the electrodeposited middle cavity layer. Structural colors are an environmentally friendly alternative to pigments and generate brighter and more efficient colors compared to pigments. However, their extensive uses at low cost are still hindered due to the complicated fabrication processes and the required expensive vacuum systems for material deposition. To address this issue, our innovation introduces an inexpensive and non-toxic bench-top electrodeposition method for the fabrication of thin film structural colors of optical quality that is entirely performed at ambient conditions without caustic reagents and without the use of any expensive ancillary equipment. Our process is compatible with highly non-planar substrates of arbitrary shape, size and roughness, which could be ideal for the coating of automobile body and many shaped interior parts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team (Saurabh Acharya, L. Jay Guo and Richard Kurtz) underwent training at the NSF I-Corps program (Fall 2019 cohort, San Francisco) wherein we conducted extensive market research and developed ecosystem maps for different customer segments by talking to a large number of potential customers (more than 100), experts, product engineers and consultants in the relevant sectors. These include the paint/pigments providers, OEM automobile, paint shops, automotive parts providers, to name an important few.

 During our customer discovery process, we interviewed potential customers in various market segments that make use of colored paints in one form or another (automotive, cosmetics, consumer electronics, fabrics). This process informed us that different sectors have very different requirement and point of interest to for their applications and needs. For example when talking with cosmetics company, the first question they ask is what materials are used in the structural colors and if they are stable. Talking to the automobile OEM and part suppliers, the most important question is the cost and scalability of the process. Many customers have asked whether our process can possibly create chrome color replacement, as the conventional chrome plating process has huge environmental impact and is being phased out. Therefore there is a real need to find a replacement for the highly desirable chrome appearance. This has prompted us to start a new research direction. When visiting a Tier 1 paint supplier for automobile OEMs, we got to know that they are typically working on colors that are could becoming trendy 5 years down the road. We also learnt an important lesson that special color pigments (like what our technology can do), when combined with traditional colors can produce very attractive visual effects. This finding can likely address the cost concerns in the first entries to market. One other insight we learnt when visiting companies working on autonomous vehicles was that vehicle coatings should have strong near-IR reflection capability in order for the IR sensors including LiDAR to work effectively. This has inspired us to develop new structural color designs for such applications.

 Based on these very valuable interviews and surveys, we have prepared and submitted a proposal to the MTRAC program supported by the Michigan Economic Development Corporation (MEDC) and cost shared by the University of Michigan, which was recently awarded. From the dialogues and interactions with our industrial consultants and business mentors, we understand that technology lifecycle and acceptance in the automotive industry is relatively long and the specification requirements are stringent. This helps us to focus our effort in this program to make rapid progress in both technical aspect and also in commercialization effort.
